Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the research of Michaela Vancliff to work in non-commutative algebra, with special emphasis on problems arising from the theory of AS-regular algebras and algebraic geometry. She is interested in the graded-module category viewed as a geometric space, with certain graded modules playing the role of geometric objects. The linear geometric modules (point modules, line modules, etc.) are parametrized by so-called linear schemes. Vancliff plans to study how the structure and role of higher-dimensional linear schemes generalize the structure and role of point schemes. Under prior NSF support, in work with T. Cassidy, Vancliff produced algebro-geometric techniques that allow the easy construction of certain AS-regular algebras (that generalize graded Clifford algebras) of any finite global dimension, naming such algebras graded skew Clifford algebras. Vancliff intends to study such AS-regular algebras of global dimension four that have finitely many points and a one-parameter family of line modules as a step towards classifying the line schemes that arise for "generic" quadratic AS-regular algebras of global dimension four. Her initial research with B. Shelton (under prior NSF support) suggests that such an algebra should have a line scheme that consists of exactly six elliptic curves, so if this is found to hold in general, then it would mimic the point scheme of generic quadratic AS-regular algebras of global dimension three (where it is one elliptic curve).

Mathematics in general is the study of patterns and frequently such patterns are described via systems of equations. For instance, systems of polynomial-style equations and their solutions play a critical role in almost every scientific field, such as statistical mechanics, elementary-particle physics, quantum mechanics, robotics, crystallography, networking, etc. Often, the solutions cannot be found by experimentation, and often they are not numbers but are functions (e.g., differential operators or matrices), and so, in general, they do not commute. The science of seeking methods that find all solutions to any system of polynomial-style equations in non-commuting variables is called non-commutative algebra. To find the solutions, the main idea is as follows. One associates to such a system of equations an entity, called an "algebra," that encodes all the properties of the original equations. Associated to this algebra are "modules," and these encode all the properties of the solutions to the equations. So, in order to find all the solutions, one should find all the modules for the associated algebra. In many of the applications, the algebras that arise in this way tend to share certain properties satisfied by commuting polynomials; such algebras are called AS-regular algebras and are the main focus of Vancliff's projects. One of the goals of the study of such algebras and their modules is to use geometric techniques to find certain modules (point modules, line modules, etc) of the AS-regular algebra, and then to use those modules to find the modules that give the solutions to the original system of equations. Vancliff's underlying goal is to improve on these geometric techniques and to understand better how they relate to the structure of the category of modules.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As explained in the Abstract for the award, the PI works in Noncommutative Algebra with emphasis on problems concerning the interaction of noncommutative algebras and geometric data. In this field, certain modules over an algebra (see Abstract) are treated as geometric objects.  The PI's overall goal is to determine what information (if any) about the algebra is depicted by geometric data associated to the noncommutative algebra.

Intellectual Merit
During the period of the award, the PI worked with several researchers (see her website for details).  With 2 Ph.D. students (Chandler and Tomlin), she wrote 3 papers concerning the line scheme of some algebras. In 2 of those papers, the line schemes are the union of (projective) curves and the PI et al found that the curves intersect at points that correspond to certain types of right ideals in the algebra. The PI also wrote a paper that surveys some results on the problem of classifying regular algebras of global dimension 4. The PI supervised her student, Tomlin, in writing an appendix for a paper written by other researchers. The PI also wrote a paper with an undergraduate student (McGinnis) concerning generalizing classical results about the transpose of a matrix. 

In work of Chirvasitu, Smith and the PI, it was found that if an algebra is similar enough to the polynomial ring on 4 variables (quadratic and regular of global dimension four) and if its line scheme has dimension 1, then the line scheme has degree 20 when it is viewed via the Plücker embedding.  This result settles a problem that had been open for almost 20 years and is likely to have an impact on the effort to classify all quadratic regular algebras of global dimension 4.  Such algebras appear frequently in statistical mechanics, elementary-particle physics, quantum mechanics, etc.

The PI worked with 4 female researchers (Sierra, Spenko, Veerapen, Wiesner) concerning generalizing some results from the 1990s regarding associating geometry to the Lie algebra sl2. The focus of the PI et al was the Lie superalgebra sl(1|1) used in string theory and a color Lie algebra derived from sl2. The PI et al found that the results from the 1990s have counterparts in these 2 other settings, and that the geometry depicts various properties of the algebra and of some of its subalgebras.

The work of Cassidy and the PI proposes a generalization, called a skew Clifford algebra (SCA), of the notion of Clifford algebra. Such a generalization has been sought for some time by physicists and the family of SCAs has some overlap with families of algebras proposed previously by other researchers, but also contains many new algebras. Cassidy and the PI also relate SCAs to graded skew Clifford algebras, which are generalizations of graded Clifford algebras.

Broader Impacts
During the period of the award, the PI graduated 2 Ph.D. students (Chandler and Tomlin) to completion of their degrees; both are US citizens. The PI helped Tomlin prepare several presentations that he used for  presenting ideas from his research to high-school students. Chandler secured a tenure-track position in 2016 at the University of North Texas at Dallas, and Tomlin is working as an instructor at the University of Colorado at Boulder.  The PI is currently supervising 3 Ph.D. students.

In 2016, the PI was a group leader in a conference organized by women for women (Women in Noncommutative Algebra and Representation Theory).  In 2017, the PI organized a special session of an AMS meeting with 2 other researchers.

The PI and her students gave various presentations during the period of the grant and the PI maintains a vibrant website that provides links to her research, selected talks, and advice for working with the computer-algebra software, maxima, and its affine package.

The PI helped her Ph.D. students organize student conferences (Graduate Algebra Symposium)  that brought together students from various universities in Texas, Oklahoma and beyond; 1 conference is held each semester and the location alternates between 3 or 4 different universities. The PI also organizes the Algebraic Geometry, Algebra and Number Theory (AGANT) Seminar.  In 2015, the PI and her colleague, D. Grantcharov, organized a campus-wide talk at the University of Texas at Arlington given by David Eisenbud; over 200 people attended, including many high-school students, their teachers and members of the local community.

The PI is an associate editor for Advances in Applied Clifford Algebras which is a Springer journal on certain topics in mathematical physics. Like most researchers, the PI referees papers for various journals. Both these tasks are unpaid and voluntary.

Since the PI and her Ph.D. students belong to groups that are under-represented in many career fields, their visibility in the mathematics arena likely encourages female students and students of ethnic or socio-economic minority backgrounds to pursue careers in science or industry or positions of leadership in society.
